li.p: The graphs of all polynomials are smooth curves without breaks or holes.
The graph of a polynomial of degree n (with positive lead coefficient) has the same long-term behavior as the power function of the same degree.

assemblage.title: Factor Theorem
assemblage.p: Let P(x) be a polynomial with real number coefficients. Then (x - a) is a factor of P(x) if and only if P(a) = 0.

li.p: A polynomial of degree n can have at most n x-intercepts.
At a zero of multiplicity 2, the graph of a polynomial has a turning point. At a zero of multiplicity 3, the graph of a polynomial has an inflection point.
The square root of a negative number is an imaginary number.
A complex number is the sum of a real number and an imaginary number.
We can perform the four arithmetic operations on complex numbers
The product of a nonzero complex number and its conjugate is always a positive real number.

assemblage.title: Fundamental Theorem of Algebra
assemblage.p: Let p(x) be a polynomial of degree n\ge 1. Then p(x) has exactly n complex zeros.

assemblage.title: Rational Function

li.p: A rational function f (x) = \dfrac{P(x)}{Q(x)} is undefined for any value x=a where Q(a) = 0. These x-values are not in the domain of the function.

assemblage.title: Vertical Asymptotes
assemblage.p: If Q(a) = 0 but P(a) \ne 0, then the graph of the rational function f(x) = \displaystyle{\frac{P(x)}{Q(x)}} has a vertical asymptotevertical asymptote at x=a.

assemblage.title: Horizontal Asymptotes
assemblage.p:
Suppose f(x) = \displaystyle{\frac{P(x)}{Q(x)}} is a rational function, where the degree of P(x) is m and the degree of Q(x) is n.
If m\lt n, the graph of f has a horizontal asymptote at y=0.
If m = n, the graph of f has a horizontal asymptote at y = \dfrac{a}{b}, where a is the lead coefficient of P(x) and b is the lead coefficient of Q(x).
If m\gt n, the graph of f does not have a horizontal asymptote.

li.p: To solve an equation involving an algebraic fraction, we multiply each side of the equation by the denominator of the fraction. This has the effect of clearing the fraction, giving us an equivalent equation without fractions.
Whenever we multiply an equation by an expression containing the variable, we should check that the solutions obtained are not extraneous.
